content.webTitle: Chris Christie, a rising star in GOP wars, hopes force awakens New Hampshire

fields.headline: Chris Christie, a rising star in GOP wars, hopes force awakens New Hampshire
fields.bodyText: To the triumphant sound of the Star Wars theme, Chris Christie drove into a New Hampshire garage on Saturday for the start of a four-day bus tour he hopes will win him the crucial state Republican primary in just six weeks’ time. Had he done so a few weeks earlier, the New Jersey governor’s confidence may have appeared as awkward as his sci-fi entrance. Then, he languished at the back of the national pack of presidential hopefuls. But Christie’s campaign in New Hampshire is drawing energy from recent polls showing him now jostling in the state with Marco Rubio – both behind a frontrunner, Donald Trump, who some believe may be brought down to earth by Ted Cruz the week before, in the Iowa caucus. Both early voting states are expected to play an even more important role than usual in the 2016 election, winnowing out a Republican field whose size has hampered attempts to compete with Trump for media attention. “You are the most powerful people in America,” Christie told an enthusiastic crowd of New Hampshire voters at a truck service centre in Exeter. “You are going to take this race from 14 people to four or five. After you vote, 10 of us go home. You are going to get to choose who the other 48 states get to choose from.” Unlike his conservative rivals, the more politically moderate Christie has wasted little time on states like Iowa and poured all of his resources into an all-or-nothing strategy to shine in New Hampshire. Saturday marked his 53rd day in the state during this campaign – more time on the ground here, he claims, than any other candidate – and brought his 38th local town hall meeting. Christie is also using his establishment pedigree as former chair of the Republican Governors’ Association to maximum effect, enlisting support from both Maryland governor Larry Hogan and the governor of the neighbouring state of Maine, Paul LePage, during the trip. “Come on, fire it up,” said New Hampshire’s senate majority leader Jeb Bradley as the crowd waited for Christie’s tour bus to pull into the garage. “We’re here to elect a president … It’s a big job for a big person.” The outsized New Jersey governor was once seen as a leading contender for the 2016 nomination, thanks to a record of bipartisan appeal in his strongly Democratic home state and a history of cooperating with President Obama in the wake of Hurricane Sandy. But a famous hug with Obama and subsequent scandal involving denying motorists access to a New Jersey bridge in an alleged act of political payback – in which he was never directly implicated – has tarnished his national reputation among both conservatives and liberals. “My original thought was I couldn’t vote for somebody from New Jersey – you know they have this reputation,” admitted former New Hampshire state representative Donna Sytek in the warm-up event, before rescuing another potentially awkward moment. “We are longing for somebody who can beat Hillary Clinton, and that person is Chris Christie,” she quickly added. The former prosecutor’s political appeal now rests firmly on a hawkish national security message and a claim to be a political outsider who has more executive experience than the insiders. “Washington is a strange place. Stay away until we put adult supervision back into Washington DC,” said Christie, who brought his four children, wife and father along as if to prove his grown-up credentials. “If you are looking for someone you agree with 100% of the time, go home and look in the mirror because you’re it. We need to do more than wring our hands.” The crowd in Exeter included many veterans and Christie warmed to a security theme he developed in Tuesday’s Republican debate in Las Vegas. “We used to control events; now events control us,” he warned. “That’s why the world is coming apart at the seams and we can feel it.” Some of the anger was directed at Obama, and by extension his former secretary of state, Clinton. “I saw that the president said the reason he don’t understand the anxiety Americans felt after Paris and San Bernardino was because he didn’t watch enough cable news,” said Christie, in reference to a New York Times report of an off-the-record presidential briefing that was subsequently removed from the paper. “Mr President, you don’t need to watch cable news if you have real-life experience.” But the real bite was reserved for Republican rivals who Christie made clear he felt were woefully under-qualified to be commander-in-chief. First in the firing line was Rubio, criticised for missing a US Senate vote on the $1.15tn budget this week. “Senator Rubio, if you are opposed to something, how about showing up to work and voting no?” said Christie. “Another one of my opponents says he is gong to carpet bomb Syria to see if sand can glow,” he added, in reference to Cruz, whom he also criticised for backing surveillance reform: “Wow, that’s tough talk. But Senator Cruz voted to weaken America and make it more vulnerable.” Trump was, oddly, not mentioned by name, and instead dismissively referred to as “a real character” who was “leading from fear, to protect his poll numbers”. “Boy, have we been entertaining,” said Christie of the race so far. “It’s been fun to watch, but showtime is over. It’s time to pick a president. We are not picking an entertainer-in-chief. This is not showtime. This is real. “I am the old truck in this race,” he concluded. “They are a bunch of shiny new trucks in this race but they haven’t been in the mud. They haven’t been tested.”
